identificationModule.officialTitle: Vitamin D and Stroke: A Comparative Study to Risk Factors and Stroke Type

responsibleParty.investigatorTitle: Associate Professor (Anesthesiology and Critical Care)- College of Medicine-Assiut University

descriptionModule.briefSummary: Stroke remains one of the most devastating neurological diseases, often causing death, or gross physical impairment. It is the second most common cause of death worldwide and a major cause of acquired disability in adults.Vitamin D deficiency has been reported to contribute to the risk of cardiovascular disease especially stroke.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: This case -control observational prospective study will conducted on fifty patients with first -ever acute onset stroke within seven days (25 patients with hemorrhagic stroke and 25 patients with ischemic stroke )

armGroups.label: Group 1 (hemorrhagic stroke)
armGroups.description: All participants will be subjected to thorough history taking, full clinical and neurological examination. Stroke subtype will be classified according to the criteria of Trial of Org 10172 in acute Stroke Treatment (TOAST) classification.

armGroups.label: Group 2 (Ischemic stroke)
armGroups.description: All participants will be subjected to thorough history taking, full clinical and neurological examination. Stroke subtype will be classified according to the criteria of Trial of Org 10172 in acute Stroke Treatment (TOAST) classification.

interventions.name: Vit D
interventions.description: It is to examine the relationship between serum 25 (OH) D levels and Stroke either ischemic or hemorrhagic types

secondaryOutcomes.description: Stroke severity will be assessed by Scandinavian Stroke scale Stroke (SSS)

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Onset is within one week
* Confirmed stroke by brain CAT and / or MRI scan either haemorrhage or infarction

Exclusion Criteria:

* Cognitive and mental changes
* Recurrent stroke
* Hepatic and renal impairment
* Endocrinal diseases
* Steroid therapy
* Vitamin D or Ca supplementation
* Previous fractures
* Bone diseases
* brain neoplasm,
* Autoimmune diseases
* History of acute and chronic inflammatory diseases
* Malignancy,
* Trauma
* Surgery
* Acute vascular diseases that occurred within four weeks prior the onset of stroke
* History myocardial infarction Ë‚3 months.
eligibilityModule.studyPopulation: patients with first -ever acute onset stroke within seven days

overallOfficials.name: sayed abd elshafy, MD
overallOfficials.affiliation: associate professor of anesthesia and critical care
